articles.title: Press release - MEPs adopt 2026 EU budget: focus on competitiveness, research and security
articles.summary: For next year’s EU budget, Parliament secured more support for research, cross-border infrastructure, border management, climate action and foreign policy.Committee on Budgets Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
In a deal with member states, reached on Saturday 15 November, Parliament obtained an additional €372.7 million for its priorities on top of what the Commission had initially proposed in its draft budget. Parliament focused on increasing funding for programmes and policies aimed at improving people's lives, boosting competitiveness, and addressing defence challenges.

Additional funding for major EU programmes

To boost competitiveness and improve cross-border infrastructure, MEPs increased funding for Horizon Europe by €20 million and for transport and energy networks by €23.5 million. Parliament secured an additional €10 million for the Civil Protection Mechanism and RescEU to improve coordination and disaster response. Playing an essential role in the EU’s defence preparedness, military mobility will get an additional €10 million. MEPs also ensured that border management will be reinforced with anadded €10 million.

The EU’s environment and climate action instrument, the LIFE programme, will receive an additional €10 million in funding, while the EU4Health and Erasmus+ programmes will benefit from a further €3 million each.

Parliament pushed for an additional €35 million for the EU’s Southern Neighbourhood, and a €25 million increase for the Eastern Neighbourhood. It also secured a €35 million increase in humanitarian aid, in response to growing geopolitical instability, accelerating global humanitarian crises, and climate change-induced emergencies.

To create new opportunities, particularly for young farmers, funding for measures promoting European agricultural products under the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund has been increased by €105 million in line with Parliament’s position.

Repayment costs for the Next Generation EU recovery package

The EU is facing an unexpected €4.2 billion increase in borrowing costs for NextGenerationEU in 2026, which is twice the amount initially projected by the Commission. MEPs ensured that this extra cost will not lead to reductions in key programmes such as Erasmus+ or EU4Health. As previously agreed, the additional costs are being handled through the “cascade mechanism”, which is intended to manage rising NextGenerationEU repayment expenses while safeguarding flagship programmes.

The total budget for 2026 is €192.8 billion in commitments, and €190.1 billion for payments, leaving a margin of €715.7 million below the 2026 multiannual financial framework ceilings in commitments for unforeseen events. More details are available in the “elements for joint conclusion”, in this background briefing and the recent press release following the deal between Parliament and Council.

The 2026 budget was adopted by 419 votes to 185, with 53 abstentions. Council endorsed the deal on Monday.

Quotes

“We live in turbulent times, with rising expectations and increasing demands on the EU budget. As citizens' priorities evolve, it is essential for the Parliament and EU institutions to listen and respond effectively. Progress is being made, but the budget alone will only get us so far. Continued efforts and further steps will be needed to enhance competitiveness,” said the chair of the Committee on Budgets, Johan Van Overtveldt (ECR, BE) said. (Watch the full plenary speech.)

“In the difficult circumstances of Russia's war of aggression, natural disasters and geopolitical pressures, we stayed focused on our priority for the 2026 budget during the negotiations with EU governments: a safer, stronger Europe. Parliament secured nearly €400 million in top-ups, reinstated cuts proposed by the Council and reinforced key programmes, for example ensuring better border protection, military mobility, and greater support for our neighbourhood and humanitarian aid. United in our position throughout the process, we delivered a solid budget for next year that focuses on a secure, stable, and stronger Europe for citizens,” said the general rapporteur for the EU’s 2026 budget (for section III - Commission), Andrzej Halicki (EPP, PL). (Watch the full plenary speech.)

“The 2026 EU budget represents the Europe we want to build: one that invests in knowledge, youth, research, environmental protection, solidarity, and humanitarian aid. We secured a strong deal that supports crucial EU programmes and key institutions, strengthens our rule of law protections and values, and delivers for our citizens. Thanks to Parliament, the agreement on additional staff and top-ups moves the Union forward, stronger - and this is something we can all be proud of,” rapporteur for the other sections, Matjaž Nemec (S&D, SI) said. (Watch the full plenary speech.)

Background

More than 93% of the EU budget goes directly into EU programmes that support people and projects across member states. The annual EU budget, which serves 27 countries and 450 million Europeans, is relatively small – on average €160 to 200 billion over the 2021 to 2027 period. This is comparable to the national budget of Poland, which serves 39 million people, or the equivalent of 30% of the budget of Germany, which serves 84 million people. (Source: Commission)

articles.personality_title: EU Parliament approves 2026 budget with extra funds for research, security, and climate action
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Each year, the European Union (EU) decides how to spend money to support its 27 member countries and their 450 million people. This money funds programs in areas like research, health, climate change, and security. For 2026, EU lawmakers worked with member states to agree on the budget.

**What happened** – On November 15, 2025, the European Parliament agreed on the 2026 EU budget of about €193 billion. They secured an extra €372.7 million on top of the original plan. This extra money will go to important programs like Horizon Europe (research), transport and energy networks, disaster response, border management, and climate projects. Funding also increased for health programs like EU4Health, education through Erasmus+, and humanitarian aid. More money was set aside to support farmers and to help neighboring countries facing difficulties.

**Impact** – This budget boosts key programs that improve daily life, protect the environment, and strengthen Europe’s safety. For example, extra funding for military mobility and border management helps the EU respond better to security challenges. Increased support for climate action and research encourages new solutions to global problems. The budget also protects important programs from cuts despite rising borrowing costs, ensuring steady progress.

**What's next step** – The Council of the EU approved this budget deal, so it will take effect in 2026. The EU will now manage the funds to support projects and policies across member states. Future budgets will continue to focus on adapting to new challenges like climate change and security needs, while supporting innovation and cooperation.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The 2026 EU budget adds significant funding to research, security, climate, and social programs, aiming to build a stronger and safer Europe for its citizens.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Parlement européen adopte le budget 2026 avec des fonds supplémentaires pour la recherche, la sécurité et le climat
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Chaque année, l'Union européenne (UE) décide de la manière de dépenser son budget pour soutenir ses 27 pays membres et leurs 450 millions d'habitants. Cet argent finance des programmes dans des domaines comme la recherche, la santé, le changement climatique et la sécurité. Pour 2026, les législateurs européens ont travaillé avec les États membres pour s'accorder sur le budget.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 15 novembre 2025, le Parlement européen a approuvé un budget de l'UE d'environ 193 milliards d'euros pour 2026. Ils ont obtenu 372,7 millions d'euros supplémentaires par rapport au plan initial. Cet argent supplémentaire ira à des programmes importants comme Horizon Europe (recherche), les réseaux de transport et d'énergie, la gestion des catastrophes, la gestion des frontières et les projets climatiques. Le financement a également augmenté pour les programmes de santé comme EU4Health, l'éducation via Erasmus+ et l'aide humanitaire. Plus de fonds ont été prévus pour soutenir les agriculteurs et aider les pays voisins en difficulté.

**Impact** – Ce budget renforce des programmes clés qui améliorent la vie quotidienne, protègent l'environnement et renforcent la sécurité en Europe. Par exemple, le financement supplémentaire pour la mobilité militaire et la gestion des frontières aide l'UE à mieux répondre aux défis sécuritaires. Le soutien accru à la lutte contre le changement climatique et à la recherche encourage de nouvelles solutions aux problèmes mondiaux. Le budget protège aussi les programmes importants des coupes malgré la hausse des coûts d'emprunt, assurant ainsi un progrès stable.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Conseil de l'UE a approuvé cet accord budgétaire, qui entrera donc en vigueur en 2026. L'UE va désormais gérer ces fonds pour soutenir des projets et des politiques dans les États membres. Les futurs budgets continueront de s'adapter aux nouveaux défis comme le changement climatique et les besoins en sécurité, tout en soutenant l'innovation et la coopération.

**En une phrase** – Le budget de l'UE pour 2026 augmente significativement les financements pour la recherche, la sécurité, le climat et les programmes sociaux, visant à construire une Europe plus forte et plus sûre pour ses citoyens.

articles.title: Ancient human foot bones shed light on how two species coexisted
articles.summary: Scientists have finally assigned foot bones found in 2009 to an ancient human species, and the move suggests that different types of hominins lived close by in harmony
articles.content:
Scientists have finally assigned foot bones found in 2009 to an ancient human species, and the move suggests that different types of hominins lived close by in harmony

The ancient human foot bones have been a mystery since they were discovered by scientists in 2009 Yohannes Haile-Selassie

The provenance of 3.4-million-year-old foot bones in Ethiopia may have finally been solved – and could prompt a rethink into how our various ancient human ancestors coexisted.

In 2009, Yohannes Haile-Selassie at Arizona State University and his colleagues found eight hominin bones, that once made up a right foot, at a site known as Burtele in the Afar region of north-eastern Ethiopia.

The find, christened the Burtele foot, included a gorilla-like opposable big toe, suggesting that whichever species it belonged to was able to climb trees.

Although another ancient hominin species, Australopithecus afarensis, was known to live nearby – most famously represented by the fossil Lucy, also found in the Afar region – the Burtele foot seemed to be from a different one. “We knew from the very beginning that it didn’t belong to Lucy’s species,” says Haile-Selassie.

The two main possibilities that gnawed at Haile-Selassie were whether the foot belonged to another species within the genus Australopithecus or a much older, more primitive one called Ardipithecus, which inhabited Ethiopia more than a million years earlier, but also had an opposable big toe.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Our Human Story Each month, Michael Marshall unearths the latest news and ideas about ancient humans, evolution, archaeology and more. Sign up to newsletter

In the meantime, the recovery of jaw and teeth remains from the same locality led the researchers to announce the discovery of a new-to-science hominin species in 2015, which they named Australopithecus deyiremeda. They suspected that the mysterious foot bones belonged to A. deyiremeda, but these were a different age to the jaw and teeth remains, so the team couldn’t be sure.

But the next year, the researchers found an A. deyiremeda’s lower jawbone within 300 metres of where the foot was recovered, with both remains being the same geological age. Based on this, the team has concluded that the foot bones belonged to A. deyiremeda.

The Burtele foot (left) and the bones embedded in an outline of a gorilla foot (right), which was similar to that of Australopithecus deyiremeda Yohannes Haile-Selassie

In another part of the experiment, where the researchers studied the carbon isotopes of the A. deyiremeda teeth, they determined that the species mostly consumed material from trees and shrubs, whereas teeth of A. afarensis indicate a diet much richer in grasses.

The discoveries prove that two species of hominin lived together in the same environment, says Haile-Selassie. The groups weren’t competing for food, so it is possible they coexisted peacefully, he says.

“They must have seen each other, spent time in the same area doing their own things,” he says. “One may have seen members of Australopithecus deyiremeda in the trees while members of A. afarensis were roaming in the grasslands nearby.”

The findings also expand our knowledge of human evolution. “Some had argued that there was only one hominin species at any given time giving rise to a newer form,” says Haile-Selassie. “Now, we know that our evolution was not linear. There were multiple closely related hominin species living at the same time even in close geographic proximity and living in harmony, suggesting that coexistence is deep in our ancestry.”

Carrie Mongle at Stony Brook University in New York says it is “exciting we are starting to get a better understanding of hominin diversity in the Pliocene [around 3 million years ago]”.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery that sheds new light on human evolution, revealing that multiple ancient human species coexisted peacefully. This finding expands our understanding of human ancestry and challenges previous assumptions about linear evolution, offering broad educational and cultural benefits.
articles.personality_title: Ancient foot bones reveal two human species lived side by side
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 2009, scientists found ancient foot bones in Ethiopia that puzzled them for years. These bones are about 3.4 million years old and came from a time when early human relatives lived in the area.

**What happened** – Researchers have now identified these foot bones as belonging to a species called Australopithecus deyiremeda. This was confirmed when they found a lower jawbone from the same species near where the foot was found, both from the same time period. The foot had a big toe like a gorilla’s, which helped the species climb trees.

**Impact** – This discovery shows that two different ancient human species lived close to each other in Ethiopia. One species, Australopithecus deyiremeda, mainly ate leaves and shrubs, while the other, Australopithecus afarensis (famous for the fossil Lucy), ate mostly grasses. Because they ate different foods and lived in slightly different places, they could live together without fighting over food. This changes how scientists think about human evolution, proving it was not a straight line but involved several species living at the same time.

**What's next step** – Scientists will continue studying fossils to learn more about how these ancient species interacted and survived. This could help us understand more about the variety of early humans and how our ancestors adapted to their environments.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The discovery of ancient foot bones shows that different early human species lived peacefully side by side, changing our view of human evolution.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des ossements de pied anciens révèlent que deux espèces humaines vivaient côte à côte
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 2009, des scientifiques ont découvert des ossements de pied anciens en Éthiopie qui les ont intrigués pendant des années. Ces os ont environ 3,4 millions d’années et viennent d’une époque où des ancêtres humains vivaient dans la région.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Les chercheurs ont maintenant identifié ces os comme appartenant à une espèce appelée Australopithecus deyiremeda. Cela a été confirmé lorsqu’ils ont trouvé une mâchoire inférieure de la même espèce près du lieu de découverte du pied, tous deux datant de la même période. Le pied avait un gros orteil semblable à celui d’un gorille, ce qui aidait cette espèce à grimper aux arbres.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre que deux espèces humaines anciennes différentes vivaient près l’une de l’autre en Éthiopie. Une espèce, Australopithecus deyiremeda, mangeait surtout des feuilles et des arbustes, tandis que l’autre, Australopithecus afarensis (célèbre pour le fossile Lucy), mangeait surtout des herbes. Comme elles mangeaient des aliments différents et vivaient dans des endroits légèrement différents, elles pouvaient coexister sans se disputer la nourriture. Cela change la façon dont les scientifiques pensent à l’évolution humaine, prouvant qu’elle n’était pas linéaire mais impliquait plusieurs espèces vivant en même temps.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques continueront à étudier les fossiles pour en apprendre davantage sur la façon dont ces espèces anciennes interagissaient et survivaient. Cela pourrait nous aider à mieux comprendre la diversité des premiers humains et comment nos ancêtres s’adaptaient à leur environnement.

**Une phrase clé** – La découverte d’ossements de pied anciens montre que différentes espèces humaines anciennes vivaient paisiblement côte à côte, changeant notre vision de l’évolution humaine.
articles.personality_title_es: Huesos de pie antiguos revelan que dos especies humanas vivían lado a lado
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2009, científicos encontraron huesos de pie antiguos en Etiopía que los desconcertaron durante años. Estos huesos tienen alrededor de 3.4 millones de años y provienen de una época en la que vivían parientes humanos antiguos en la zona.

**Qué pasó** – Los investigadores ahora han identificado estos huesos como pertenecientes a una especie llamada Australopithecus deyiremeda. Esto se confirmó cuando encontraron una mandíbula inferior de la misma especie cerca del lugar donde apareció el pie, ambos de la misma época. El pie tenía un dedo gordo parecido al de un gorila, lo que ayudaba a esta especie a trepar árboles.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento muestra que dos especies humanas antiguas diferentes vivían cerca una de la otra en Etiopía. Una especie, Australopithecus deyiremeda, comía principalmente hojas y arbustos, mientras que la otra, Australopithecus afarensis (famosa por el fósil Lucy), comía principalmente pastos. Como comían alimentos diferentes y vivían en lugares un poco distintos, podían vivir juntas sin pelear por comida. Esto cambia cómo los científicos piensan sobre la evolución humana, demostrando que no fue una línea recta, sino que varias especies vivieron al mismo tiempo.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos seguirán estudiando fósiles para aprender más sobre cómo estas especies antiguas interactuaban y sobrevivían. Esto podría ayudar a entender mejor la variedad de los primeros humanos y cómo nuestros antepasados se adaptaron a su entorno.

**Una frase clave** – El descubrimiento de huesos de pie antiguos muestra que diferentes especies humanas antiguas vivían pacíficamente lado a lado, cambiando nuestra visión de la evolución humana.

articles.title: Defying the odds: Young entrepreneurs vow to take their chances and build the industries of tomorrow
articles.summary: Young people make a vital contribution to the creation of industries that benefit people and the planet. Their role was recognised on Wednesday at Generation Future day of the Global Industry Summit in Riyadh, with commitments to ensure that their voices are heard and their ideas shared more widely.
articles.content:
With a 90 per cent failure rate for startups, you could forgive young people if they concluded that founding a company, particularly at such a turbulent time for the global economy, would be too risky an option.

“But there's a 10 per cent chance of improving people's lives,” retorts business management student Daniel Wu, boldly taking the “glass slightly full” approach. “If nobody takes that 10 per cent chance, then nobody's going to succeed in the future.”

Mr. Wu’s project to build a digital skills platform for rural youth, to teach them about AI and software skills, made it to the finals of the Innovation Youth Competition run by the UN Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO).

This led to an invitation to attend the UNIDO Global Industry Summit in Riyadh where, on Wednesday, he took part in a session focused on the Youth Parliament, a global debate platform organized jointly by UNIDO and Saudi Arabia’s Ministry of Industry and Mineral Resources (MIM).

The many young business minds at the Summit were brimming with enthusiasm and a desire to make the most of the networking opportunities on offer, with the chance to meet mentors, policymakers and potential investors.

The programme featured a series of interactive dialogues; innovation highlights and mentorship sessions. Young delegates presented pioneering solutions in renewable energy, circular economy practices, and digital manufacturing. These exchanges provided opportunities for policymakers and industry leaders to engage directly with youth, exploring how their ideas can be scaled and implemented across diverse contexts.

UN News/ Conor Lennon Daniel Wu, finalist in the Innovation Youth Competition run by the UN Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO).

‘We know how our generation thinks’

They will need to retain that positivity in the face of the statistics: added to the large failure rate, they are also hampered by slim track records, in comparison to older entrepreneurs. This doesn’t put off Mr. Wu, who argues that young people are worthy of investment due to the unique perspective they can offer.

"We grew up with computers, with the internet, and we know how people engage with different types of content. We have a good understanding how our generation, the next big market segment, thinks, which is why we have a better edge compared to older investors.”

By dedicating an entire day to youth, the Global Industry Summit sent a clear signal: the future of industry will be defined not only by established leaders but by the creativity, determination and resilience of the next generation. In Riyadh, that future was given a powerful voice.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

It focuses on a significant event, the Global Industry Summit, which amplifies youth voices and ideas with potential broad impact. Policymakers and business leaders will explore ways to support these young innovators and bring their ideas into real-world industries. articles.title: Spain will be the first country to exit European surveillance after receiving a bailout
articles.summary: Brussels.- Spain will exit the European supervision program at the end of this year after the banking rescue it received from the European Union (EU) since it will have already repaid 75% of it, making it the first country in the bloc to leave this monitoring system.
articles.content:
Brussels.- Spain will exit the European supervision program at the end of this year after the banking rescue it received from the European Union (EU) since it will have already repaid 75% of it, making it the first country in the bloc to leave this monitoring system.

This is reflected in the report published this Tuesday by the European Commission (EC) and the European Central Bank (ECB), the last of this surveillance cycle, which states that the outlook for the Spanish economy is “favorable” despite some “vulnerabilities,” that public finances “continue to improve,” and that the banking sector is “profitable” and “resilient to risks.”

Once Spain makes the next scheduled payment of 4.6 billion euros in December, it will have repaid more than 75% of the 41.333 billion it received in 2012 and 2013 to clean up and restructure its banking sector, allowing it to move past the semi-annual visits from community institutions to assess its economic and financial situation.

The exit will come sooner than expected since Spain has made several voluntary repayments in recent years to accelerate the return, which should be completed by 2027.

Strong Growth

In the report, the EC and the ECB note that the economic outlook is favorable, but warn that there are vulnerabilities that need to be analyzed, such as geopolitical tensions, low productivity growth, rising labor costs, and bottlenecks in housing supply.

Public finances, they note, “continue to improve,” with a reduction in the deficit to 3.2% of GDP in 2024 despite the cost of aid due to the flooding and debt rising to 101.6% of GDP thanks to “strong economic growth,” increased tax revenue, and the gradual elimination of energy subsidies.

These factors also favor Spain’s ability to maintain a good capacity to pay its public debt, the institutions state, which consider the financing conditions of the central government to be “favorable” and point out that the reduction in the risk premium (the differential with German bonds) indicates “continued market confidence in Spain.”

However, they point out that the increase in the cost of outstanding debt, although from low levels and gradually, combined with the high public debt ratio requires “close attention.”

Financial Sector

Regarding the financial sector, they highlight its profitability and resilience to risks, but note that the capitalization of Spanish banks has only slightly improved as entities “have opted for significant dividend payments and share buybacks” and that the CET1 maximum quality capital ratio (13.6%) is the lowest in the EU, although it meets European requirements.

The risks to financial stability, they point out, are “contained” and are mainly linked to global geopolitical tensions, as well as weak economic growth and currency devaluation in key foreign markets, such as Latin America, while internally, recent increases in housing prices, new mortgages, and loan-to-value ratios “could justify greater vigilance.”

In addition to Spain, Greece, Portugal, Ireland, and Cyprus are subject to this type of post-rescue surveillance until they repay at least 75% of their respective rescues, which, unlike the Spanish one, were not limited to banking. (November 25)

articles.personality_title: Spain set to leave EU bailout supervision after repaying most of its bank rescue loan
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Spain received a large financial rescue from the European Union in 2012 and 2013 to help fix its struggling banks. As part of this help, Spain agreed to regular checks by EU institutions to monitor its economic progress.

**What happened** – Spain will end this EU supervision by the end of 2024 after repaying more than 75% of the 41.3 billion euros it borrowed. The European Commission and the European Central Bank reported that Spain’s economy is doing well enough to stop these regular reviews. Spain has even made extra repayments early to speed up this process.

**Impact** – This is the first time a country in the EU has fully repaid a banking bailout and ended the related supervision. It shows Spain’s banks are now more stable and profitable, and the country’s public finances have improved. The move signals growing trust from investors and better economic health after years of recovery.

**What's next step** – Spain will continue repaying the remaining bailout loan, aiming to finish by 2027. Meanwhile, EU institutions will keep watching other countries that received rescues. Spain will also need to stay careful about risks like rising debt costs and housing market changes.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Spain will be the first EU country to exit bailout supervision after repaying most of its bank rescue loan, marking a major step in its economic recovery.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Espagne prête à quitter la surveillance européenne après avoir remboursé la majeure partie de son prêt bancaire
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Espagne a reçu une aide financière importante de l’Union européenne en 2012 et 2013 pour sauver ses banques en difficulté. En échange, elle a accepté d’être surveillée régulièrement par les institutions européennes pour suivre ses progrès économiques.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’Espagne mettra fin à cette surveillance européenne fin 2024 après avoir remboursé plus de 75 % des 41,3 milliards d’euros empruntés. La Commission européenne et la Banque centrale européenne ont indiqué que l’économie espagnole allait suffisamment bien pour arrêter ces contrôles réguliers. L’Espagne a même effectué des remboursements anticipés pour accélérer ce processus.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois qu’un pays de l’UE rembourse entièrement un sauvetage bancaire et met fin à la surveillance associée. Cela montre que les banques espagnoles sont désormais plus stables et rentables, et que les finances publiques du pays se sont améliorées. Cette décision témoigne d’une confiance accrue des investisseurs et d’une meilleure santé économique après des années de redressement.

**Prochaine étape** – L’Espagne continuera de rembourser le reste du prêt, avec pour objectif d’achever le remboursement d’ici 2027. Par ailleurs, les institutions européennes continueront de surveiller les autres pays ayant reçu des aides. L’Espagne devra aussi rester vigilante face à certains risques comme la hausse du coût de la dette et l’évolution du marché immobilier.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’Espagne sera le premier pays de l’UE à sortir de la surveillance du plan de sauvetage après avoir remboursé la majeure partie de son prêt bancaire, marquant une étape importante dans sa reprise économique.
articles.personality_title_es: España se prepara para salir de la supervisión europea tras devolver la mayor parte de su rescate bancario
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – España recibió una gran ayuda financiera de la Unión Europea en 2012 y 2013 para salvar sus bancos en problemas. A cambio, aceptó ser supervisada regularmente por las instituciones europeas para seguir su progreso económico.

**Qué pasó** – España terminará esta supervisión europea a finales de 2024 tras devolver más del 75 % de los 41,3 mil millones de euros que pidió prestados. La Comisión Europea y el Banco Central Europeo informaron que la economía española está lo suficientemente bien como para detener estas revisiones periódicas. España incluso ha realizado pagos anticipados para acelerar este proceso.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que un país de la UE devuelve completamente un rescate bancario y finaliza la supervisión relacionada. Esto muestra que los bancos españoles son ahora más estables y rentables, y que las finanzas públicas del país han mejorado. El movimiento indica una mayor confianza de los inversores y una mejor salud económica tras años de recuperación.

**Próximo paso** – España continuará devolviendo el resto del préstamo, con el objetivo de terminar en 2027. Mientras tanto, las instituciones europeas seguirán vigilando a otros países que recibieron rescates. España también tendrá que estar atenta a riesgos como el aumento del costo de la deuda y los cambios en el mercado inmobiliario.

**Conclusión en una frase** – España será el primer país de la UE en salir de la supervisión del rescate tras devolver la mayor parte de su préstamo bancario, marcando un paso importante en su recuperación económica.
